Situation1: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story: I was scrubbing the hallway floors, watching the dust swirl in the sunlight, when I noticed how much grime had built up along the baseboards. The house had been busier than usual, and I felt the weight of my responsibility as a cleaner—every corner needed to shine, every surface spotless. I grabbed my supplies, determined to tackle the mess before it grew worse. Just as I knelt to start, my phone buzzed. It was a reminder: Mrs. Evans was coming in half an hour. She’d asked for spiritual guidance, her voice trembling with worry when she called. As a priest, I knew how much she needed someone to listen, to offer comfort and counsel. But the dust nagged at me, a visible sign of neglect, and I felt torn. The house demanded my attention, but so did Mrs. Evans’ troubled heart. My mind raced, heart pounding, as I weighed the expectations—should I finish cleaning, or prepare myself to be fully present for her? The mop felt heavy in my hands, and I stood frozen, caught between the demands of cleanliness and compassion, unsure which role to serve first.
